Chi-Square Test of Independence with Effect Size

Source: R/categorical_tests.R
chisq_test.Rd

Conducts chi-square test of independence for contingency tables with Cramer's V effect size and standardized residuals. Publication-ready output for JCP standards.

Usage

chisq_test(data = NULL, x, y, correct = TRUE, simulate_p = FALSE, B = 2000)

Arguments

data

Data frame (optional if x and y are vectors)

x

Character (column name) or vector (first categorical variable)

y

Character (column name) or vector (second categorical variable)

correct

Logical. Apply Yates' continuity correction for 2x2 tables? (default TRUE)

simulate_p

Logical. Use Monte Carlo simulation for p-value? (default FALSE)

B

Integer. Number of Monte Carlo replicates if simulate_p = TRUE (default 2000)

Value

A list with class "chisq_result" containing:

  • statistic: Chi-square statistic

  • df: Degrees of freedom

  • p_value: P-value

  • cramers_v: Cramer's V effect size

  • effect_interp: Effect size interpretation

  • n: Total sample size

  • observed: Observed frequencies table

  • expected: Expected frequencies table

  • residuals: Standardized residuals

  • cells_low_expected: Cells with expected count < 5

  • use_fisher: Recommendation to use Fisher's exact if needed

  • interpretation: Publication-ready text

  • publication_text: APA-style results statement

Details

**Cramer's V Effect Size:** - For 2x2 tables: V = sqrt(chi^2/n) - For larger tables: V = sqrt(chi^2/(n x min(rows-1, cols-1))) - Interpretation: 0.10 = small, 0.30 = medium, 0.50 = large

**Assumptions:** - Expected frequency >= 5 in all cells (for 2x2) - Expected frequency >= 5 in 80 - If violated, use Fisher's exact test instead

**Yates' Correction:** - Applied by default for 2x2 tables - Makes test more conservative (reduces Type I error) - Can turn off with correct = FALSE

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# From data frame
result <- chisq_test(
  data = customer_data,
  x = "condition",
  y = "purchased"
)

# From vectors
condition <- c(rep("A", 50), rep("B", 50))
purchased <- c(rep(c("yes", "no"), each = 25),
               rep(c("yes", "no"), c(35, 15)))
result <- chisq_test(x = condition, y = purchased)

print(result)
} # }
